_meta.scenario: High renewable penetration — solar flooding midday
_meta.description: GridAlpha Demo Mode deterministic snapshot. Scenario: PJM peak solar event (June 15 2025 13:00 EPT). Solar 38.5% of load. LMP suppressed in western zones. RECO has highest spark spread. Battery arbitrage $42/MWh net in eastern corridor. VIRTUAL_SELLER convergence signal active.
_meta.envelope_note: All data sections now follow the standard ApiResponse envelope: meta / data / summary.

summary.market_narrative: Wind and solar suppressed Real-Time prices below Day-Ahead forecasts — virtual sellers who sold RT and bought DA were profitable.

data.market_note: AEP zone solar generation is flooding the midday market, suppressing Real-Time prices well below Day-Ahead — a textbook solar cannibalization event.
Natural gas combined-cycle units are price-setting in AECO due to high local demand and limited solar penetration along the NJ coast.
Solar generation in APS is setting the marginal price, depressing midday prices across the Mid-Atlantic/West Virginia corridor.
Nuclear baseload in ATSI is price-setting during this solar-saturated period, providing stable low-cost output in northern Ohio.
Maryland solar is flooding the BGE zone at 13:00 EPT, pushing RT prices $17 below Day-Ahead commitments.
Strong Illinois wind is the marginal unit in COMED, keeping prices suppressed and making virtual sellers profitable.
Dayton-area solar is at peak output, causing RT prices to undershoot Day-Ahead forecasts by over $15/MWh.
Nuclear units are price-setting in DEOK, with low marginal cost maintaining grid stability despite the system-wide renewable ramp.
Virginia solar is at peak output in DOM zone, suppressing prices and outcompeting gas for the marginal MWh.
Natural gas combined-cycle is the marginal fuel in DPL zone, with Delmarva demand exceeding local solar output.
Nuclear baseload is price-setting in DUQ zone during this solar-heavy midday, with Cheswick coal having retired.
Coal remains the marginal fuel in EKPC zone, with Kentucky's renewable penetration remaining below system average.
Natural gas is price-setting in JCPL zone; congestion from PJM-West limits renewable imports into central Jersey.
Solar in METED is suppressing midday prices in north-central Pennsylvania, creating arbitrage opportunities for storage operators.
Coal is the marginal fuel in OVEC zone — the last major coal-heavy area as retirements loom for Kyger Creek and Clifty Creek.
Gas combined-cycle is the price-setter in PECO zone; Philadelphia area demand keeps gas on the margin despite widespread solar.
Gas combined-cycle is marginal in PENELEC zone in northwest Pennsylvania, with aging coal capacity retired since 2023.
DC-area solar is flooding the PEPCO zone, creating negative spreads between Real-Time and Day-Ahead pricing.
Systemwide solar penetration is at 38.5% of load, making it the dominant marginal fuel for PJM's 13:00 EPT interval.
Solar is price-setting across the PPL zone in eastern Pennsylvania, with RT prices running $22/MWh below Day-Ahead.
Natural gas combined-cycle units are the marginal price-setters in PSEG zone; congestion limits flow from solar-rich areas.
Natural gas is the marginal fuel in RECO zone — congestion at the Raritan Valley interface creates a $23/MWh premium over adjacent zones.

data.investment_signal: Critical capacity gap in BGE zone after Brandon Shores and Crane retirement. 1,381 MW deficit even accounting for replacement queue. High-value siting for Gas-CC or grid-scale Storage.
Severe Appalachian capacity shortfall — 3,611 MW gap as Ohio/Indiana coal retires. Dispatchable peakers or CCGT most urgently needed before 2027.
COMED zone near capacity balance. Large Midwest renewable queue partially offsets retirements; dispatchable backup is needed for low-wind, dark periods.
Growing capacity risk in DOM zone. Virginia offshore wind is a key hedge but deliverability constraints and nuclear retirements widen the gap.
DUQ zone faces moderate deficit as Cheswick retires. Limited queue depth makes Gas-CC or pumped storage the most impactful investment.
PSEG zone capacity tightening as aging gas-fired plants retire. Offshore Wind development is critical for long-term reliability in the NJ corridor.
PENELEC zone carries high retirement risk — 1,482 MW of coal retiring through 2028. Remote area limits build opportunity; Storage and Gas-CT most favored.
OVEC zone faces large capacity gap as Kyger Creek and Clifty Creek retire. Small queue and limited transmission create systemic reliability risk.
PJM system faces a 20+ GW capacity gap by 2028. Renewable queue growth is insufficient on a capacity-credit basis. Dispatchable investment is critical before 2027-2028 auction settlements.

sync_status.message: GridAlpha Demo Mode active — serving deterministic demo snapshot. Scenario: high renewable penetration, solar flooding midday (2025-06-15 13:00 EPT). No live API calls were made.
